etymology.description: Depicts a man with legs bending -> indicating a corpse's posture -> linked to lying or resting position in ancient scripts
etymology.interpretation: 尸(尸) (shī, "corpse") is a pictogram depicting a person in a position indicating death, mirroring a sitting or lying posture. This form captures the essence of a non-living body.

examples.chinese: 他在山洞中发现了尸(屍)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài shāndòng zhōng fāxiàn le shī.
examples.english: He discovered the corpse in the cave.

examples.chinese: 考古学家在墓穴中找到了尸(屍)，他立即通知了当局(當局)。
examples.pinyin: Kǎogǔ xuéjiā zài mùxué zhōng zhǎodào le shī, tā lìjí tōngzhī le dāngjú.
examples.english: The archaeologists found the corpse in the tomb, and they immediately informed the authorities.

examples.chinese: 夜幕降临时(夜幕降臨時)，古庙前那具尸散发出阴森气息(古廟前那具屍散發出陰森氣息)。
examples.pinyin: Yèmù jiànglín shí, gǔ miào qián nà jù shī sànfā chū yīnsēn qìxī.
examples.english: As night fell, the corpse in front of the ancient temple emitted a eerie aura.
